Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Bridging the Gap between the Transcriptome and the Proteome to Study Inter-cellular Signaling
Award.AbstractNarration:
Systems biology promotes studying physiological processes along multiple lines of inquiry simultaneously. However, technologies to capture some types of data (e.g., gene expression levels) are more advanced, more comprehensive, and less expensive than methods to obtain other types of data (e.g., protein levels). To remove this gap, this research will develop a well-principled approach to prioritize expensive and time-consuming proteomic experiments based on data collected from transcriptional experiments. The team will drive these analyses using novel and sophisticated algorithms to compute directed Steiner acyclic graphs. They will use their methodology to study a fundamental question in biology: how do different cell types communicate with each other in the complex environment found in tissues and organs? They will address this question using a novel in vitro three-dimensional liver mimic that contains two different hepatic cell types in a layered configuration. The educational component of this project will infuse computational thinking into biology and engineering at the undergraduate level via a summer research institute on "Computationally-Driven Experimental Biology in Engineered Tissues" to four undergraduate students, consisting of lectures on project-related topics and a single collaborative research project. Involving all the students in a single research project will expose them to team science and give them an appreciation of how computer science, tissue engineering, and experimental cell biology can be seamlessly interwoven to study cellular processes.

By developing innovative solutions to study inter-cellular signaling, this project will pave the way for advances in inter-cellular and organ-level systems biology. This project will develop a combined computational-experimental pipeline by integrating new proteomic data with existing measurements in order to refine our models and algorithms. The methodology, algorithms, and software will be a valuable addition to the emerging set of tools that use computational analysis to prioritize new experiments. The research, software, and data resulting from this project will be made available at http://bioinformatics.cs.vt.edu/~murali.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary focus of this project was to develop an integrated computational-experimental methodology to understand how cells communicate with each other in complex tissues. More specifically, we sought to discover how internal signaling pathways were perturbed in a cell type upon receipt of cues from other cell types. We used the principles and approaches of network biology wherein we modeled signaling pathways as networks. Our experimental system was an in vitro model of the liver, which is the primary organ that detoxifies foreign compounds ingested by the body. 

Network biology algorithms. Pursuant to these goals, the project advanced the field of network biology and liver tissue engineering along several fronts. 

  1. The PathLinker algorithm is a state-of-the-art approach for reconstructing the proteins and interactions within signaling pathways. Its accuracy is superior to those of similar methods by a wide margin. We were successful in experimentally validating novel connections suggested by PathLinker. This automated method can complement slow and painstaking manual curation that is used currently to create databases of signaling pathways. It also promises to serve as a powerful approach for discovering the structure of poorly studied processes and prioritizing both proteins and interactions for experimental study.
  2. The XTalk algorithm is a novel path-based approach to predict when signaling pathways may crosstalk. This method also outperforms its competitors significantly. In conjunction with this algorithm, we also created XTalkDB, the first database that explicitly records evidence in the literature for crosstalking pathways.
  3.  We developed the notion of signaling hypergraphs to accurately represent reactions involving proteins in signaling pathways. The representation of interaction networks (graphs) that is in vogue now has the drawback of not being to represent complexes and multi-way reactions among proteins and complexes. Signaling hypergraphs do not have these restrictions. 
  4. We developed GraphSpace (www.graphspace.org), an easy-to-use web-based platform that collaborating research groups can use for storing, interacting with, and sharing networks. Anyone can upload and share networks at http://graphspace.org. GraphSpace solves several challenges faced by interdisciplinary research teams in network biology in sharing, exploring, and interpreting computed networks in their collaborations.

All the software developed in this project is available under free/open source licenses.

Tissue engineering. We developed a powerful 3D organotypic liver model in this project. This model consisted of three important cell types in the liver. Two of these cell types were separated from the third (hepatocytes) by a polyelectrolyte membrane, which simulated the physical separation and the three-dimensional stratified structure found in the liver in vivo. We observed that only the 3D organotypic hepatic model simultaneously supported proliferation of all cell types and maintained cell ratios observed in vivo. This advance was highly significant since other in vitro hepatic cultures show significant deviation from in vivo cellular composition, a factor that may limit their physiological relevance. We used a number of tests to demonstrate that our system maintained the phenotypes of all three cell types simultaneously for up to 12 days. The liver mimic exhibited significantly enhanced detoxification capability in comparison to 2D co-cultures of liver cells. In summary, we have designed a powerful and versatile new 3D liver mimic that addresses a longstanding open problem in hepatic tissue engineering.  This liver mimic is a promising new vehicle for future studies on engineered hepatic tissues, drug metabolism, and toxicology

'Omics analyses. We comprehensively measured the transcriptome and proteome in the liver models and analyzed them using computational methods to discover several insights into liver biology. These results supported our motivating hypothesis that the polyelectrolyte membrane played a critical role in maintaining a physical barrier between hepatocytes and other cell types, while promoting cellular interactions through soluble molecules.  

Broader impacts. This project supported two female post-doctoral fellows (PDFs) and six Ph.D. (two female, three graduated), two M.S. (both graduated) and four B.S. (all graduated) students. PDF Allison Tegge received the F32 fellowship from the NIH in 2013. PDF Anna Ritz joined the Department of Biology at Reed College as an assistant professor in 2015. The project also trained six undergraduates (three women, two minority) in team science spanningcomputer science, tissue engineering, and proteomics. The training activities resulting in this award assisted in the establishment of the "Computational Tissue Engineering" interdisciplinary graduate education program (http://cte.cs.vt.edu) supported by the Graduate School at Virginia Tech.
